Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Collaborative Research: A General Theory of Group Testing for Genotyping

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Next generation high-throughput sequencing devices have brought the promise of personalized genotyping to the field of human genomics. Advances in personalized genotyping depend on developments of procedures for cost-efficient large-scale association studies. Such large-scale experiments and studies face a number of obstacles related to constraints imposed by bioengineering systems and test subjects, including a) the restriction that tests have to be performed with small samples of individuals' genetic material; b) the constraint that subjects have to be multiplexed, so that genetic sequences have to be barcoded; c) the fact that the outcomes of the tests are semi-quantitative; d) the reality that many tests have to be performed within groups of related individuals, thereby significantly increasing the cost of screening whole families; e) the fact that tests have to deal with the challenge of variant discovery and individuals that may exhibit different gene copy numbers. A natural way to overcome these and many other obstacles is to perform genotyping via group testing.
The goals of this project include developing of a comprehensive, yet analytically or computationally tractable general theory of group testing for genotyping. The proposed theory will answer the unique challenges arising in genotyping by sequencing, although parts of the theory may find independent applications in areas as diverse as constrained multiple access channel analysis, fingerprinting and identification coding, and error-control coding. In particular, the investigators introduce several new models into the field of group testing, including subjects with different types and strengths, semi-quantitative testing, two-dimensional pooling, and Poisson probabilistic testing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A group testing scheme is a way of designing a screening experiment that supports efficient detection of defective items in a large by performing a small number of carefully designed tests that involve groups of subjects rather than individual subjects. Constructions of explicit group testing schemes constitute a difficult unresolved problem. In this project we proposed new ways of constructing and analyzing group testing schemes by allowing a small probability of identification error in exchange for a reduced number of tests required for identification. The group testing schemes proposed in this project are based on methods of encoding information for transmission over communication channels (error correcting codes). We use mathematical methods of probability theory to estimate the error probability of identification of the proposed schemes.  The outcome of this research provides new ways of constructing probabilistic group testing schemes and rigorous methods of estimating the error rate.

Generalizing the methods developed in the first part of the project, we considered applications of error correcting codes to the construction of sampling matrices for sparse signal recovery. It is known that recovery of sparse signals from a small number of samples can be performed in an efficient and noise-resistant way if the samples are constructed using matrices with the so-called restricted isometry property. Just as in the case of group testing schemes, explicit constructions of sampling matrices form a difficult question. We considered a probabilistic relaxation of the restricted isometry condition under which this property is satisfied for most but not all samples. With this relaxation it becomes possible to construct and analyze large families of sampling matrices formed from error correcting codes and other related geometric objects.

Broader impacts of this research are attained through dissemination of results. A part of the findings of this project will be included in the plenary talk at the 2016 IEEE International Symposium on Information Theory presented by the PI.
